form.official-title: To amend the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a program under which the Secretary will award grants to specialty crop producers to acquire certain equipment and provide training with respect to the use of such equipment.

section.header: Automation and mechanization grants for specialty crops producers
section.text: Subtitle A of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 (7 U.S.C. 1621 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: For purposes of enhancing the competitiveness of specialty crop producers in the United States, the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Administrator of the Agricultural Marketing Service, shall establish a program under which the Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to acquire certain equipment and provide training with respect to the use of such equipment.
An eligible entity receiving a grant under this section shall use funds received through the grant—

paragraph.text: to acquire mechanized or automated systems and tools that increase the efficiency of a task or reduce human labor for a specific activity, as determined by the Secretary; and
to provide training, including worker training, and other professional services required to learn how to deploy and effectively operate such systems and tools, as determined by the Secretary.

subsection.text: To the maximum extent practicable, the Secretary shall seek to ensure that the amount of a grant awarded to a single eligible entity is sufficient to provide a significant offset to the costs such eligible entity incurs in carrying out the activities specified in subsection (b).
The recipient of a grant under this section shall provide non-Federal matching funds equal to not less than 50 percent of the amount of the grant.

paragraph.header: Mechanized or automated systems and tools
paragraph.text: The term mechanized or automated systems and tools includes—

subparagraph.text: low dust harvesting tools and equipment;
grinding and chipping tools and equipment;
phytosanitary, infrared, and pasteurization tools and equipment;
storage and warehousing tools and equipment;
drones for monitoring commodity piles and feedstuff for cattle;
wireless, networks, and connectivity equipment to support IoT devices;
remote, mobile, or drone sensing sensors for field level monitoring of environmental variables for use in farm production or processing management decision making;
enhanced precision irrigation automation, remote sensing, and metering, pest and disease detection, nutrient analysis, and crop load assessment equipment and tools;
crop monitoring and analytics equipment and tools;
potential and predictive near-infrared crop damaged assessments;
robotic, semi-autonomous, autonomous, or mechanized systems or other tools;

equipment and tools that automate or mechanize seeding, weeding, harvesting, packing (field and in-house), pruning, spraying, transporting, or climate protection (such as shade cloth or light manipulation); and
such other automated or mechanized systems or tools that increase efficiency, as determined by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The term eligible entity means an individual or entity engaged in the commercial production of specialty crops in the United States.
